repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
the current implementation of iterators had the following bugs:
- it was possible to assign `const_iterator` to `iterator`
- it was not possible to assign `iterator` to `const_iterator`
- operator* did not always return `value_type` e.g. for
  `const_iterator` this often returned `T&` instead of
  `const value_type&`
- increment operators always returned `iterators`. This caused
  e.g. `const_iterator + 1` to result in a `iterator` instead of
  a `const_iterator`
- comparision operators could not be used to compare
  `iterators` and `const_iterators` (`const_iterator == iterator`)

comment_data.body:
I believe this was incorrect, since the `const_*` versions appear to be a hack since cython does not understand when to use the const and non const versions of this function. However now that the iterators work as expected I would personally prefer:
```cython
cdef test(const vector[int]& x):
     cdef vector[int].const_iterator iter = x.begin()
```
or if C++11 is used
```cython
cdef test(const vector[int]& x):
     iter = x.cbegin()
```

over
```cython
cdef test(const vector[int]& x):
     cdef vector[int].const_iterator iter = x.const_begin()
```
or
```cython
cdef test(const vector[int]& x):
     iter = x.const_begin()
```

since it is closer to the actual C++ code you would write
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -73,9 +98,11 @@ cdef extern from "<vector>" namespace "std" nogil:
         void pop_back()
         void push_back(T&) except +
         reverse_iterator rbegin()
-        const_reverse_iterator const_rbegin "crbegin"()

comment_data.body:
I am not super happy with this, but this appears to be an already existing work around so it plays well with cythons code gen. It appears cython derives the return type:
`std::map<T, U>::value_type` even though it actually returns the reference `std::map<T, U>::value_type&`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -7,32 +7,58 @@ cdef extern from "<map>" namespace "std" nogil:
         ctypedef pair[const T, U] value_type
         ctypedef COMPARE key_compare
         ctypedef ALLOCATOR allocator_type
+
+        cppclass const_iterator
         cppclass iterator:
+            iterator() except +
+            iterator(iterator&) except +
+            # correct would be value_type& but this does not work
+            # well with cython's code gen
             pair[T, U]& operator*()

comment_data.body:
This adds operators which would be required in C++ to do
```cpp
std::vector<int>::iterator x;
++x;
x++; // this operator is added in this PR
x += 5
```
Cython currently appears to ignore whether these operators exist (see https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4533), so currently they are not strictly necessary in Cython. However it probably still makes sense to define all existing operators since this might change at some point.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9,36 +9,109 @@ cdef extern from "<deque>" namespace "std" nogil:
         ctypedef size_t size_type
         ctypedef ptrdiff_t difference_type
 
+        cppclass const_iterator
         cppclass iterator:
-            T& operator*()
+            iterator() except +
+            iterator(iterator&) except +
+            value_type& operator*()
             iterator operator++()
             iterator operator--()
+            iterator operator++(size_type)
+            iterator operator--(size_type)
             iterator operator+(size_type)
             iterator operator-(size_type)

comment_data.body: So â€¦ should we fix the type inference/analysis for this?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -7,32 +7,58 @@ cdef extern from "<map>" namespace "std" nogil:
         ctypedef pair[const T, U] value_type
         ctypedef COMPARE key_compare
         ctypedef ALLOCATOR allocator_type
+
+        cppclass const_iterator
         cppclass iterator:
+            iterator() except +
+            iterator(iterator&) except +
+            # correct would be value_type& but this does not work
+            # well with cython's code gen
             pair[T, U]& operator*()

comment_data.body: This would probably make sense, but is outside the scope of this PR. I will open another issue for this.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -7,32 +7,58 @@ cdef extern from "<map>" namespace "std" nogil:
         ctypedef pair[const T, U] value_type
         ctypedef COMPARE key_compare
         ctypedef ALLOCATOR allocator_type
+
+        cppclass const_iterator
         cppclass iterator:
+            iterator() except +
+            iterator(iterator&) except +
+            # correct would be value_type& but this does not work
+            # well with cython's code gen
             pair[T, U]& operator*()

comment_data.body: Thinking about this again I am unsure whether we can really do better. `std::pair<const T, U>` can not be reassigned to. However this is required in out case, since we define the variables at the top of the function and only assign the value later.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -7,32 +7,58 @@ cdef extern from "<map>" namespace "std" nogil:
         ctypedef pair[const T, U] value_type
         ctypedef COMPARE key_compare
         ctypedef ALLOCATOR allocator_type
+
+        cppclass const_iterator
         cppclass iterator:
+            iterator() except +
+            iterator(iterator&) except +
+            # correct would be value_type& but this does not work
+            # well with cython's code gen
             pair[T, U]& operator*()

commit.message:
fix incorrect iterator implementation

the current implementation of iterators had the following bugs:
- it was possible to assign `const_iterator` to `iterator`
- it was not possible to assign `iterator` to `const_iterator`
- operator* did not always return `value_type` e.g. for
  `const_iterator` this often returned `T&` instead of
  `const value_type&`
- increment operators always returned `iterators`. This caused
  e.g. `const_iterator + 1` to result in a `iterator` instead of
  a `const_iterator`
- comparision operators could not be used to compare
  `iterators` and `const_iterators` (`const_iterator == iterator`)
